div.p: The first day in a new job can be pretty overwhelming for anyone regardless of the workplace.
I’m a science program officer at Fisheries and Oceans Canada
(also known as DFO) in the Maritimes Region.
I’ve only been here for about six months, but I absolutely love my job – and today,
I am helping a new employee transition to DFO through our departmental orientation program.
She’s brand new – just like I was six months ago,
having just moved here from Montreal into my first full-time government job.
So I pretty much know what this new person – her name is Jolene – is going through this morning.
The first day can be pretty overwhelming for anyone, regardless of the workplace,
so the Government of Canada aims to make the first day transition as smooth as possible.
As Jolene and I are about to take the elevator to the Science Branch, two people join us.
And not just ANY two people, but our manager and our regional director.
I really can’t resist taking the opportunity to introduce Jolene
to them, so I do it!
They seem pleased to meet her so we all had a brief chat on the way up to five.
Afterwards, Jolene and I make our way to the Science Branch where we have our weekly meeting.
This meeting is a great opportunity for Jolene as she will get a chance to meet new people,
and get a real understanding of the work we do in the region,
how the local offices report to the regional office,
and how the regional office reports to headquarters.
Before I know it, it is time for lunch, so we decide to head to the cafeteria.
There’s a little group of us that always get together for lunch.
We all play Ultimate on the same team,
and we all worked on the Government of Canada Charitable Workplace Campaign together.
Denise is on the Communications team,
and she explained how they do everything from internal work
to stakeholder-focused communications, plus media enquiries.
She loves it because it’s flat out all the time!
Raj works in Human Resources.
They do everything from organizational planning to job postings to pay and benefits.
Tony works with Security.
He helps employees get their security passes and identification cards.
Allison works in Finance, where she oversees the regional budget,
and Max is on the Information Technology team - or IT -
that is focused on things like activating e-mail accounts or providing access to computers.
After lunch, I deliver Jolene back to her new team and say goodbye.
After even half a day, I have a really good feeling that she’s going to fit in well,
and bring a lot to the team…
… not just because she understands the structure and the functional areas,
but because she really got to see for herself that DFO is a family…
just like I did.
